greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Least number m such that n is the denominator of sigma_{-1}(m), or zero if no such exists.
comment: First occurrence of n in A017666.
Conjecture: a(n) is never zero. Checking up to 1000000, the smallest number not found is 210; and a(210) = 26611200.
n|a(n), since sigma_{-1}(n) = sigma(n)/n. a(n) = n for n any prime power (and many others).
Up to 1000, the maximum value is a(330) = 1890345600. - _Michel Marcus_, Aug 14 2012
Actually, a(n) = n, for n in A014567. - _Michel Marcus_, Dec 28 2013
Up to 10000, the largest term is a(9570) = 22033432080000. - _Giovanni Resta_, Mar 22 2014
link: Michel Marcus and Giovanni Resta, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000 (first 1000 terms from Michel Marcus)
mathematica: a[n_] := Catch[ For[ lim = Quotient[2*10^9, n]*n; k = 0, k <= lim, k = k + n, If[Denominator[ DivisorSigma[-1, k]] == n, Throw[k]]; If[k >= lim, Throw[0]]]]; a[1]=1; Table[ an = a[n]; Print[{n, an}]; an , {n, 1, 1000}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Aug 14 2012 *)
results.author: _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Jul 08 2009
